Rabies cases on the rise in northern Thailand
Dr. Thawichai of the Department of Disease Control said on February 9 that rabies infections have increased in the northeast of Thailand over the past few months, with a total of 74 cases.
So far this year (October 2019 - September 2020) there have been 67 and 7 cases of rabies in Surin and Buri Ram provinces in the northeast, respectively, for a total of 74.
All of them have been vaccinated against rabies in the past.
He urged people to get their pets vaccinated against rabies and to avoid contact with saliva from animals suspected of being infected.
Rabies can be transmitted to humans from cats and bats as well as dogs.
Once a person is infected and symptoms appear, they are almost always fatal, but vaccination before symptoms appear can prevent death.

FUJI Develops System to Prevent Accidents Caused by Vehicles Leaving the Road; Tests Conducted with Own Vehicles | Central Japan Economic Newspaper: Economic Information for Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka Prefectures
FUJI (head office in Chiryu), which manufactures and sells robots and machines for installing electronic components, has started developing a system to prevent "abandonment" of children in cars.
The system is set up so that when a motion sensor detects movement in the car, a notification is sent to the driver's phone or chat.
The company is currently conducting a trial using its own shuttle buses.
While also preventing the painful accidents that occur when children are left behind.

Currently, the company is conducting a demonstration experiment using two of their own vehicles for the after-school English conversation program for children, "teracoya THANK," which is operated in Chiryu City.
Three motion sensors that detect human movement from the temperature difference between humans and their surroundings are installed in the ceiling of the car.
If the engine is turned off and the door is closed, and the sensor detects movement after a certain amount of time has passed, an automatic warning notification is sent.
By coordinating the engine and door status and information, it is possible to prevent false detection as much as possible.
The warning notification is sent via the cloud.
In addition to calling the number registered in advance, it will also be displayed on the computer or smartphone chat.
You can register multiple addresses, and they take care to avoid mistakes such as forgetting to do so.
The trial will continue until the end of February.
Kamiya Ichikazu, the head of the second section of the innovation promotion department, pointed out that "during the experiment, we also saw issues outside of the system."
For example, they were able to pick up various challenges related to school buses, such as creating an environment that allows drivers to concentrate on driving.
"We will put our strength into expanding the solution."
The development of the prevention system was triggered by a series of accidents involving abandoned buses across the country.
Employees with young children suggested that there was nothing that could be done to protect their children's safety.
They decided to develop the system, using the knowledge they had gained from their FA (Factory Automation) related business, such as IoT (Internet of Things) and sensor-based information management.
FUJI's abandonment prevention system is easy to use.
The sensor can be installed by simply pinning it to the ceiling.
Since it can be easily retrofitted to the shuttle bus, it is easier to introduce and aims to be widely adopted.
In the future, they will be looking to collaborate with kindergartens and nurseries, as well as considering productization.

With Valentine's Day on February 14th, chocolate prices are rising due to the high cost of raw materials and packaging, but sales of high-priced chocolates for personal use and for family and friends are doing well.
In Fukui Prefecture, retailers and confectioners are trying to attract customers by offering products that emphasize local flavor, high quality, and attention to materials.
The Seibu Fukui store (Fukui City) opened a special sales area on the sixth floor on January 25.

Sandwich-style products using Fukui-made sake and chocolate, as well as chocolate-covered sandwiches, are popular.
According to the store representative, the price of the products has risen by about 10 percent compared to last year.

"This year, there are many products that stand out for their use of high quality materials and luxurious packaging. As for consumer trends, it seems that people are buying for themselves and their families and enjoying the food."
Despite the unfavorable economic climate, sales of high-priced items are doing well.

"We are focusing on creating a sales floor that allows customers to enjoy Valentine's Day itself," the representative said.

Kiseki (Kiseki) is a series of original chocolates that was jointly developed by the French chocolate maker and the Western confectionery club Kura-Fu (Kura-Fu) (head office: Sakai City, Maruo-cho, Ichibonodai, last year), and this is the first time that they have used the series in Valentine's Day sales.

In the Fukui Prefecture food industry, which is struggling with a shortage of staff, there is a growing trend to introduce robot waiters that deliver food to the tables.

The robot's cute expressions are popular with families, and it also helps to reduce the number of staff needed to run the store and prevent the spread of COVID-19 by providing "contactless" customer service.

Local restaurant owners and related parties are saying, "It's hard to secure employees and part-time workers for local restaurants, so the robotic food delivery service will become even more widespread."
"Jin, Jin, Jin-Jin-Khans!"
The robot, which displays a cat's face on the screen while playing light music, carries the food and glides smoothly through the restaurant.
When it arrives at the table, it will say something like "I have your order, Nyah" to the customer.
The "Jingisukan Hontou Fukui Ekimae" restaurant in Otake 2nd Street, Fukui City, introduced a cat-shaped serving robot in August 2022.
The robot, which is stationed near the kitchen, picks up the ordered dish from the customer and presses the table number on the screen, then autonomously drives to the table and delivers the food.
It has an AI (artificial intelligence) voice function and responds when customers touch it, and its cat face on the screen is expressive.
Bon-ta Group, which operates the restaurant, has introduced the robot in two stores, including this one.

Saito, the president, said, "The biggest reason for the introduction is the shortage of manpower," and emphasized that it is part of the production efficiency improvement through the digital transformation (DX).
The ratio of labor costs to sales at the store is usually around 30%, but it has been reduced to 21-22% by the introduction of the robot.

The robot also has the role of collecting plates when customers have finished eating, which contributes to the efficiency of cleaning up, and "it is also good for families and children, and has a promotional effect."
The "Rikkaisei Yamafuku Fukui" restaurant, which serves grilled meat and hormone soup, also introduced a serving robot in August 2022.
"I thought it was absolutely necessary to introduce it to solve the personnel shortage," said Yoshimura Eifukucho President of Sonsan Shoten, who runs the store.
In the Fukui store, the range of the robot's delivery is divided from the range of the employee's delivery.
The rental fee for the robot is about the same as the salary of one part-time worker.
In order to reduce the number of staff, the store has introduced an order system using tablet terminals in addition to robots, and is also considering self-service.
According to the Fukui Labor Bureau, the ratio of job seekers to job openings in the "customer service" category, which includes restaurants, was 6.94 in December 2022, making it a high-demand job.

"We are receiving many inquiries about introducing robots because the labor shortage in restaurants in Fukui Prefecture is getting worse due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic," said a representative of the online system (2-chome, Takagi-cho, Fukui City) that sells robotic food-preparation machines.
Hoshiyama said, "I think it will be even more difficult to secure employees in local stores in the future, and I think that meal delivery robots will become more common."
[Opinion] Echizen Town is creating an engagement notebook and distributing it to residents who wish to receive it.

Last year, when they issued the "okuyomi handbook" which covers the necessary procedures and written wills, as well as genealogical charts and other forms of inheritance lists, they found that many people came to pick them up for themselves.

In various parts of the prefecture, there are also courses on how to write an obituary and how to organize your affairs before you die, and it seems that "end-of-life activities" have become a fixture in the lives of the prefecture's citizens.
Echizen Town's Ending Note is 35 pages.

Chapter 5 begins with a review of one's life, and then one writes down their current health status, financial situation, future care needs, wishes for end-of-life medical care, and preferences for funeral and burial.
There are also columns for things to do in the rest of your life and messages to important people.
It's hard to write that there are 35 pages, but you don't have to fill all of them.
What do you want to leave behind for your family and others.
The important thing is to make your intentions clear.
There are many different notebooks available in shops that are tailored to different purposes, and it is recommended to start writing from the beginning.
It was in 2009 that the word "endgame" was coined, alongside the idea of career endgame.
Two years later, in 2011, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred.
Many people have come to realize the reality that "death comes suddenly," and there are more people who are preparing for their own end and the end of their lives.
It's been 10 years since then.
The worldwide coronavirus pandemic is still ongoing.

With the rise in prices due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the unprecedented price hike in electricity bills this winter, the question of how to prepare for the end of life has become more pressing.
On the other hand, wages have not increased as much as prices, and many people are worried about the future.
Meanwhile, the cost of a funeral, care, burial management, etc., which could be shared by relatives and friends, is now a rarity in the era of single children.
There is also the dilemma of a longer life span, but with a higher risk of dementia and care needs as we age.
It is worth bearing in mind that the fact that end-of-life care is becoming a permanent fixture is also linked to the rise in social anxiety.
Either way, nobody wants to burden their partner or children with excessive expenses.
The idea of "dignified death" is a popular keyword in the funeral industry, but it is not something that should be taken too far.
Rather than keeping your wishes and preferences to yourself, it's a good idea to discuss them with your family and make arrangements in advance.

"Dear Prime Minister, the Breakwater of Life" from Tōjinbō, a book published by the NPO organization "Heart-touching Collection and Editorial Office"
"Dear Prime Minister, 'Breakwater of Life' from Tōjinbō" is the 10th book that they have published at their own expense.
The book has been featured in newspapers across the country, and many readers have sent in their own impressions.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the contents of the "social and structural" environmental issues that are the cause of suicide in Japan, which were directly heard from those who attempted suicide, and to create a "society that is good to live in" with the hope of establishing a "society that is good to live in."

We have been patrolling the water's edge of Tōjinbō, Fukui Prefecture, which is called a suicide spot, for 18 years and 10 months to prevent suicide, and we continue to support those who have been discovered and protected by us to re-start their lives.

The book is a summary of the problems heard from the 784 people (as of 2/6) that have been protected so far, and it makes the following seven points to the Prime Minister about the necessary national policies to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2) Behind suicide there are "human rights violations" piled up.
(3) Suicide victims are victims of social and structural organized crime.
(4) The administration treats citizens living outside the jurisdiction as "outsiders" and gives them cold treatment.
(5) People with mental disorders such as depression are medicated and treated as "accidents" even if they commit suicide.
(6) "Duty of care" in high-risk suicide areas is forgotten and commercialism is rampant.

(7) The future is threatened by the practice of fraudulently inducing people to provide money by threatening them with future harm, based on the teachings of new religious movements, which cannot be scientifically proven.
Religious groups that engage in these criminal acts of fraud and extortion should be exposed and expunged.

So, we have received some very nice comments from people who have bought the book, such as "I was moved by the strong mental of the people who are working on this project", "The former police officer looks like a police officer", "He is a living Buddha who supports others as if they were his own family, even though they are not", and I would like to introduce one of the comments here.
I saw a photo in a newspaper article and tears came to my eyes.
I hear that suicides are increasing among those who are being pushed to the brink by the pandemic.
It is a VERY SAD "life" really.
Everyone is who they are.
I hope that we can live in a society where we can enjoy the life we have been given.
I felt respect and gratitude towards all the staff who are putting their hearts into helping those who are carrying such a heavy burden of wanting to die.
I hope you will continue to support us and ask for our help, as I believe this is a very demanding activity on both the mind and body.
Thank you.
KASHIKO
I hope that everyone who is a reader becomes a gatekeeper of life in their region.

Toba City is demanding the return of double payment of child-rearing allowance - Ise Shimbun

Toba City announced on the 10th that a total of 600,000 yen was mistakenly paid to 11 households with 12 people in the fiscal year 2021 Child Raising Family Living Support Special Allowance (Other Household Allowance).
The city will apologize to the recipients and explain the background, and then request that they follow the procedure to return the money.
The city said that the discovery was made on January 27, 2023, after a parent of a child who had previously received the payment brought it to the city's attention.
After checking all 79 households and 182 people who were eligible for the support in the same year, it was found that 11 households and 12 people had received the support twice on July 20, 2020.
The city has provided 50,000 yen per person as a grant to children under the age of 18 in non-taxed households.

The city received data from the computer company it hired to extract the target children, but the staff member mistakenly added the data to the list, thinking that high school students were not included, and the money was paid twice.
The person in charge of the city's childcare support room said, "We will take this situation seriously, thoroughly check the data, and make every effort to restore trust by preventing a recurrence."

Introducing the pioneers of plant research, including Hayachine Mountain collection materials, in the City General Cultural Property Center Exhibition [Hanamaki] | Iwanichi Online Iwate Nippo

An exhibition titled "People who introduced the flowers of Hayachine - A small history of Hayachine plant research" featuring the pioneers who laid the foundation for the study of alpine plants in Hayachine mountain is being held at the Iwate Prefectural Comprehensive Cultural Property Center in Oohasama, Hanamaki City until the 12th.
The exhibition features 124 items, including valuable specimens collected by the pioneers, and introduces the footsteps of the pioneers involved in the study of plants on Mt. Hayachine.

The study of plants on Mt. Hayachine began with the Russian botanist Karl Ivanovich Maximowicz (1827-1891), who came to Japan in the late Edo period, and Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), who was born in Shiwa-cho and collected plants under Maximowicz's guidance.
Unable to freely walk around the country for foreigners, Maksimowitsch asked Sukawa to collect, and continued his research for three years, based in Yokohama and Nagasaki.
After Maksimowitch returned to Russia, Suzuka continued to support his research, which led to the publication of the Hayachine's unique Primula macrocarpa, Sanguisorba obtusa, and Aruncus dioicus.

Later, modern botanist Makino Fusatarō (1862-1957) published "Nangtora no" "Kobanotsumekusa" "Nanginunazuna" and "Katoahebe" in 1903 (Meiji 36) based on the collections of local researchers, and "Katoahebe" was discovered and named by Makino himself when he climbed Mt.
From the exhibit materials, it can be seen that many researchers have revealed the precious alpine plants.

The exhibition also introduces the work of Sumimura Masanosuke (1874-1948), who was a botanist and accompanied the survey of natural monuments in 1927, and Tamakawa Shirō (1914-1988), who worked as a museum curator at the Ōhasama Mountain Museum and also contributed to the publication of "Plants of Hakihō."

"There is a lot of research and human connections behind the name of each plant on Mt. Hayachine," said Yoshida, a researcher at the center. "We can trace the connections between researchers from the local area to the whole country."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters, with the first chapter focusing on the beliefs and history of Hayachine, and the second chapter using the research of Heinrich Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), a German geologist who laid the foundation for Japanese geology, to spotlight the characteristics of Hayachine from a geological perspective.
All Lines in Iwate Prefecture to be Suspended in a Row, JR|Iwanichi Online Iwate Nippo Newspaper

Due to the influence of the heavy snow, the JR local lines in the prefecture have been suspended on the 10th, with the following lines affected: North Line, Hanawa Line, Yamada Line, Ofuna-Tsugaru Line, Kamaishi Line, and Hachinohe Line.

According to JR Sendai Station, the Kitakami Line saw three trains between Yokote and Sendai suspended, affecting around 80 passengers, while the Ofunato Line saw four trains between Ichinoseki and Kesennuma suspended, affecting around 280 passengers.
The same branch office announced the schedule for the JR Ishinomaki Line on the 11th, stating that heavy snow was expected.
The Kitakami Line from Fukushima to Yokote will not operate from the first train to around 9:00 AM, and some trains on the Kitakami Line from Kitakami to Fukushima will be suspended.

The Ofunato Line will have service from Ichinoseki to Kesennuma from the morning until around 5:30pm, and the Kamaishi Line will have service from Morioka to Kamaishi from the morning until around noon, and service from the morning until around 11:00am on the down line.
The Tohoku line will also suspend some trains on the up and down lines.
The schedule may be changed depending on the weather conditions.

Idlib Province in northwestern Syria, which was hit by the earthquake = 9th before dawn (provided by local residents, Kyodo)

[Kazanbul, Turkey] According to the authorities of Turkey and Syria, which were affected by the earthquake that originated in southern Turkey, the number of confirmed deaths on the 9th exceeded 21,000 in both countries.
Rescue efforts to pull survivors from collapsed buildings and other debris are being complicated by the harsh weather.
Searches are continuing in the affected areas.
The United Nations said on the 9th that it had delivered aid to the Idlib province in northwestern Syria, which was hit by the earthquake on the 6th, through the Turkish border for the first time.

Idlib province was the last stronghold of anti-regime rebels fighting against Assad's forces in Syria's civil war, and there were concerns that it would be the next to fall without international support.
Rescue efforts using heavy machinery are continuing in both countries, but are facing difficulties.
Many are believed to be buried under the rubble and the death toll is likely to rise.
Turkish authorities have confirmed 17,674 deaths in Turkey.
The death toll in Syria, which is over 3,000, has made it the worst disaster since the 1999 earthquake in northwestern Turkey, which killed more than 17,000 people.

Amami Airport hosts second decarbonization promotion council meeting to discuss reintroduction of renewable energy and goals | Society & Economy | Nankai Daily
Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council Meeting Held to Discuss Decarbonization Efforts in Kasari, Amami City, on September 9th.

The "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Takahashi, Chief of the Construction Section of the Amami Island Subprefecture, 13 members) which is made up of the prefecture and airlines that use the airport, held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All members, including those online, attended.
The meeting discussed the setting of decarbonization goals and the exchange of opinions on the introduction of renewable energy, with solar power as the main focus.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a total goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions at each airport by 46% (compared to 2013) by 2050, with the aim of achieving zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.
In response, the council held its first meeting in November last year, and is aiming to establish a plan ahead of other airports on other islands in the prefecture.
The second meeting was closed to the public, as was the first.
After the meeting, Atō Chairman, who responded to the press, said that the meeting confirmed the greenhouse gas emissions of the airport.
They said that they will continue to discuss the guidelines of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism in order to set goals and introduce renewable energy.
According to the distribution materials, the benchmark 13th year's CO2 emissions from the airport's equipment and vehicles was 1,476 tons (excluding aircraft).

Of these, the emissions from lighting and air conditioning in seven facilities, including airport terminal buildings, account for about 90 percent, followed by airport lights at 84 tons and airport vehicles at 71 tons.
The council will discuss reducing the emissions of these facilities and vehicles.
Ando said, "We are at a turning point. The direction of the committee members is in line, and I would like to firmly compile the interim report."
In the future, the third meeting will hear opinions on the interim report, and the fourth meeting will hear opinions on the final report, and then the plan will be formulated.
"Reverse Real Estate" Okinagawa Ryubu Branch Office Opens to Bring People to the Island, Homeowners Recruit Tenants | Society & Economy | Minami-Kyushu Nishi Shimbun
Opening event to deepen understanding of "sakasama real estate" through talk sessions, etc. = August 8th, Chinacho

The opening event for the Oki-Eryu-Ryu branch of the "Sakasama Real Estate" service, which matches people who want to rent out vacant houses or shops with landlords, was held on August 8th at the community center "entaku" in Chinacho.
The operating company explained the outline of the service through the talk session.
Tsukinoba (Hokkaido Rishiri) President Director, Okubo Shouhoku, said, "If we do this on Okinoerabu Island, we can create a movement that brings people to the island, and create a flow."
Unlike normal real estate, Sasamano Real Estate works by displaying information about people who want to rent and then contacting landlords, who can then make their own agreements.

As a proof of concept to uncover potential vacant homes and build relationships through vacant homes, the service was launched in June 2020, and is operated by On-Co Co. Ltd. (headquarters Mie Prefecture).
The opening of the branch office is the seventh in the region of Kyushu.
It is the first time in the country for an island.
About 20 people participated in the event, including On-Co and Tsukinohara staff, town hall employees from Wakkabara and Shimane, and local residents.

Okubo, the representative director, explained the process of opening the branch office, saying, "As the movement to bring people from outside the island is gaining momentum, I thought that if we could utilize vacant houses and vacant stores, the town and the island could become even more lively."

"I want to help people who have properties on the island and people who want to do something by connecting them and helping them to carry out their efforts, even if it's just one person and one property," he said.

On-Co representative, Mizutani Gakushi, said, "We need to take each empty house seriously and discuss with the locals what they want to do with the area, who they want to come and live here, and what criteria they want to use."
"The more people are connected, the more information will be gathered," he appealed for participation in discussions and cooperation in providing information.

Professional burglars (thieves) have knowledge of security cameras.
It seems that even though it's small, it's a high-performance camera and can distinguish between recording.
On the other hand, it's a pain if you're not a pro.
However, as recent burglaries are bold and sophisticated, I would recommend using a combination of various security gadgets, not just cameras.
For example, you can get a white solar LED garden light at a hardware store for around 1,500 yen (the latest is very bright and has 6 lights).
Since it's solar, I don't have to pay for electricity, but since it doesn't turn on until morning in the winter, I also have 3 100V human-sensing LED sensor lights installed.
With this combination, I was able to ensure that I could recognize human figures from a distance of 30m.
Also, for daytime security, if you feel that the camera's small size makes it less intimidating, you might want to consider a cover.

It is more effective to use the manufacturer's product than to use what is sold at home centers.

Persona 4 is complete on Vita.

As a game, I found 5 easier to play than 3.
Persona 3 is mostly blue, so it's hard to see the backgrounds.
5 has bright colors like red and yellow as the main colors, so they are easy to see even if they are covered by the background.
With the abundance of assist features, I think even those who are not good at games can enjoy it.
For those who are used to playing games, the challenge feature will make it a more challenging game.
The triple pack comes with the soundtrack, which is a solid 4 disc set, so if you like the music from Persona, I would recommend this one.

I used the SIM free iPhone 7s.

At first setup, I didn't know what to do after I got to Korea and pointed my SIM, so I asked a woman at the SK counter at Gimpo airport (just turn data roaming on from settings > mobile communication > communication options) and it worked out fine.
The instructions that came with the product didn't seem to be very relevant...?
The thing is, I've been having a hard time getting 3G in the Gimpo airport area, which is notorious for bad reception.
When I went out into the city, it switched to 4G.
In the evening and night, the communication became very heavy sometimes, but I think I may have reached the maximum limit of a few hundred MB per day.
